 The point is pretty straightforward I would think. Being that just because one group takes a stand and is noted for one thing (notably their view of civil rights, in the case of the KKK), that doesn't automatically mean other issues fall along the same lines.
 
 I think you know as well as I do that Matthew's hope is that the KKK's view on this will damage the Christian movement that believes homosexuality is wrong. He hopes for damage-by-association. But that hasn't worked with people like Fred Phelps . . . the evangelical movement has been no worse off even with people like Matthew who like to associate Phelps with evangelicals at large. So there's little reason to think it will work by associating the KKK with evangelicals. Furthermore, evangelicals can still certainly dissociate amd condemn the KKK and still maintain their stance on gay rights.
 
 Even though the KKK generally has very bad views, this idea that "the KKK likes it so it's gotta be bad" just isn't a very rational way to approach the matter. The issue should be argued and viewed on it's own merits, not by the groups who happen to prefer one side of it over the other. I think people in general know this, which is why there's been little outcry over things like Robert Byrd's associations with the KKK even though he's a well-know Democratic senator.
